FOREIGN FISHING BOATS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

This Bill amends the Foreign Fishing Boat Levy Act 1981, which imposes a levy in the grant of licences to foreign fishing boats not exempted under the Act. At present the classes of exempted vessels include those licenced under an agreement with a foreign government and those temporarily imported for use by and under the control of Australians and deemed to be an Australian vessel in accordance with Section 4 (2) of the Fisheries Act 1952. The only fishing agreements Australia has with a foreign government are with Japan and the Republic of Korea. All other foreign vessels licenced to operate in the Australian fishing zone are liable to pay levy unless there is a formal agreement requiring the foreign operators to provide other benefits to Australia, in consideration of which the Minister may waive the levy.

In recent years, it has been necessary to conclude agreements with Australian principals covering the processor/carrier vessels used by the southern bluefin tuna fisherman last season to facilitate the processing and transport of sashimi quality tuna to the Japanese market. These vessels generate significant benefits for Australia and the purpose of the agreements is to provide a basis for waiving the levy in such cases. However, the conclusion of a formal agreement required under the Fisheries Act 1952 to achieve this is complex and time consuming. The proposed amendment to Section 4 of the Principal Act will simplify the Adminstrative processes necessary for exempting those foreign vessels, whether temporarily imported or not, which are operated by or on behalf of, or in accordance with the instructions of Australians and confer benefits on Australia.

The amendments proposed in clauses 5 and 6 relate to the payment of fees for access by foreign interests other than a foreign Government to the Australian fishing zone. Foreign fishing vessels may be licensed to fish in the Australian fishing zone under agreements. Agreements may specify the total access fee to be paid to Australia. To secure the payment of the lump sum access fee under the Principal Act in its present form, a levy is prescribed, calculated by dividing the total access fee by the agreed number of boats to be licensed.

If fewer than the agreed number of boats apply for a licence, a portion of the access fee, although paid previously as part of the total lump sum payment of the fee, remains unauthorised under the present legislation. This produces a loophole which is open to legal challenge.

The Bill closes this loophole by providing proper statutory authority for collecting the full amount of lump sum payments specified in any agreement irrespective of the number of licenses issued. Other amendments are of a machinery nature.
The Bill has no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
FISHERIES AGREEMENTS (PAYMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985
This Bill amends the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Act 1981 in parallel with the amendments proposed by Clauses 5 and 6 of the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Amendment Bill.

The Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Act 1981 authorises the refusal of licences for foreign boats unless amounts specified in agreements between Australia and a foreign government with respect to operations of those boats in the Australian fishing zone have been paid to Australia.
The amendment proposed by clause 4 of the Bill will extend the power to refuse licences to cover fisheries agreements between Australia and one or more parties who are not foreign governments.

The Bill requires the Minister to have regard only to the terms of such an agreement when deciding whether or not to license foreign boats under the agreement. It also prevents the issue of any such licences unless the amount has been paid to Australia in the manner specified in the agreement.
The Bill has no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 September, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Amendment Bill 1985 was debated in the Senate on Wednesday of last week. The Bill provides for a number of amendments to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation which is the remnant of the once great organisation which constructed the Snowy Mountains scheme in Australia. Let me make it perfectly clear that I am not critical of this body as an engineering corporation. In the past it was probably one of the great Australian organisations.
—It still is.

—The comment from the Government side is that it still is. I do not dispute that but the question which the Opposition parties have raised is why the employees of this organisation are still public servants. It was okay for the Australian Government to be in the business of engineering when we lacked engineers of this calibre at a time when we wanted to construct an enormous scheme such as the Snowy Mountains scheme but Australia now has a number of very competent engineering bodies, including this one, and there is no massive government requirement for engineers as there was in the late 1940s and early 1950s. The Opposition is, therefore, of the view that there is no need for this body to continue as a government body. It really should be in the private sector with all other engineering bodies of similar ilk in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: When this matter was last debated, I referred to the Corporation's statement of profit and loss for the year ended 30 June 1984 and I pointed out that it had an operating loss of over $5.4m. I indicated to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) that the Opposition would be seeking the profit and loss figures up to 30 June 1985 at the resumption of debate on this Bill. It took the Corporation only three months to prepare the figures for 1984 and I see no reason why it cannot provide us with the figures for 1985 in the Committee stage. I was also pointing out that, although it is not disclosed in the balance sheet of the Corporation, by some fairly simple deduction it appears that this body may very well have liabilities of around $15m for superannuation and retirement allowances for its staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much of that has already been funded?

—We will be interested to know. I hope that the Minister will be able to tell us what is the liability, how much of it has been funded and where the funds for it are retained. I have some difficulty in discovering them in the balance sheet, which shows that the capital made available by the Government in 1983 was $2.6m and in 1984, $6.6m; in other words, during 1983-84 the Government gave this body $4m. I would be interested to know how much the Government gave this body during 1984-85 and how much it intends to give it during 1985-86. We will ask the Minister those questions at the Committee stage of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Government proposes with this legislation is somehow or other to extend the life of this body by putting it in a privileged position vis-a-vis the private sector. Of course, it will be in a privileged position because it is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Australian Government and as such it is able to borrow unsecured funds. It gets all sorts of advantages. What the Government also proposes is to allow this body to enter into agreements with overseas corporations and generally to move into a number of areas in which the legislation indicates that as best as it is able to it will act as an Australian body involving Australian organisations so far as is practicable but in effect it will be able to expand its overseas activities and indeed its activities in Australia.

I happened to be a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations when that Committee inquired into the affairs of the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries. Mr Deputy President, you may recall that there was considerable concern about the activities of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd, which was a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Australian Dairy Corporation. When the Senate Committee reported-I point out that the report on this section was unanimous and, for instance, the Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, was a member of that Committee at the time-it indicated its grave concern about the creation of subsidiaries by statutory authorities. It pointed out that at the time of the report there were at least 42 wholly or majority owned subsidiaries of Commonwealth statutory authorities. It indicated that this practice was growing and that authorities were tending to create their own subsidiaries. It pointed out that at that time there was no legislative necessity for authorities, when creating subsidiaries, to seek parliamentary or ministerial approval or even to inform the Parliament or the Minister.
The report indicated that of the 42 wholly owned or majority owned subsidiaries, 18 were created without prior ministerial approval. The report stated:
In no case was prior Parliamentary approval obtained nor was the Parliament informed at the time of incorporation.

The important thing about that is that this Parliament sets up the statutory authorities. It is not the Government but the Parliament which passes the legislation which establishes an authority. For an authority, having been established by an Act of Parliament, to be able to create a subsidiary without even bothering to tell the Parliament that it has done so is, I believe, contemptous of the Parliament. It is something which the Committee reported should not be allowed to continue in the future.

Another problem with statutory authorities was revealed by that investigation. This was that Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd apparently had wider powers under its memorandum and articles of association than did the Australian Dairy Corporation, its parent authority. What in fact happens is that a statutory authority created by the Parliament has certain powers. Without telling the Parliament that it was going to do so, that authority created a subsidiary which had wider powers than the authority which was established by Act of Parliament. The Committee unanimously reported that that sort of thing should not happen in the future. Paragraph 16.11 of the Committee's report states:
The Committee further considers that it is inappropriate for authorities to create subsidiaries without prior ministerial approval.

One can understand why a Minister ought to be told before an authority creates a subsidiary. The Committee considered whether the Parliament ought to be informed before a subsidiary was created but it said: `No, we will not go that far and require the authority to let the Parliament know, but the Parliament should be informed within a reasonable time after the incorporation'. What the Comittee recommended was that the relevant Minister be required to inform the Parliament within 15 sitting days of the establishment of a subsidiary and to table the memorandum and articles of association or other constitutional documents of the subsidiary so that the Parliament could see what the subsidiary had been set up to do.

When I looked at this legislation which the Government has brought before the Senate, I discovered that the Government had not taken up that recommendation in the Committee report. I had a discussion with my colleague Senator Archer, and with Mr Beale in the other place, as a result of which we have prepared, and the Opposition will move at the Committee stage of the Bill, amendments to clause 7 which cover the points that I have raised, which I acknowledge are not my points but points raised by a Committee of the Senate. My recollection is that that recommendation was a unanimous one. I have indicated the nature of those amendments and they have been distributed around the chamber. I endeavoured to make them available to the Australian Democrats on Friday but I understand that I was not successful and that the Democrats did not receive them until this morning; thus they may have had some difficulty in giving them consideration until fairly recently. Also, I did not make them available to the Government until I had finalised the precise wording I intended to use and was sure that I would use that wording. I made them available to the Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr West, in the other place earlier this afternoon, about two hours or so ago, in the hope-

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you think it was a bit rough to give that sort of notice?

—Senator Siddons asked if I consider that to be a bit rough. I acknowledge that it is a bit rough to do that, but it is the sort of thing that happens in Parliament. In any event, there is a rule called the two-hour rule which enables Ministers of the Crown to give the Opposition shadow Ministers no more than two hours notice of making all sorts of decisions. No doubt the first time that the Opposition Treasury spokesman will find out what the Government will do with its tax deal will be about two hours before the Treasurer (Mr Keating) makes the announcement in the House of Representatives. So the Government has had two hours notice of an amendment which, quite frankly, Government departmental officers ought to have picked up and ought to pick up all the time, in regard to statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge to the two Ministers sitting in the chamber at present-the Minister for Education and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt)-that when we were in government, as a back bencher I endeavoured to persuade our Ministers to accept this sort of amendment. I had the devil's own trouble because Ministers seemed to be swamped by their departmental officials who said that it would be difficult. I cannot see that there is any difficulty about this. All it means is that if the authority wants to create a subsidiary-after all, it is not like buying a packet of chips; it will not be creating a subsidiary very often-it should first seek the approval of the Minister. I do not think that any Minister of the Crown would find that an unreasonable suggestion.

The second suggestion is that when the subsidiary has been created the Minister will have 15 sitting days-it could be up to a month or six weeks, or even longer if it happened during a parliamentary recess-in which to come into the Parliament and say: `This authority, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, has set up a subsidiary. The subsidiary's name is such and such and this is the copy of its memorandum and articles of association', or that `the Corporation has entered into a partnership agreement or some other arrangement and these are the terms and conditions of the new subsidiary which has been created.' It seems to me that that proposition is most reasonable. I would have thought that it is the sort of proposition that any Minister of the Crown, knowing his or her responsibilities to the nation, would be willing to adopt. I will be interested to see the Government's reaction to that proposal.

In conclusion, I repeat what I said earlier, that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation really is in a position where it ought to be sold to the engineers and other officers who in fact are running it. It ought to be sold on terms and conditions which make it quite a reasonable, viable proposition for them to continue the operation in their own way, being fully financially responsible for their own investment, rather than committing the organisation to a lingering death, which is what this Government is doing at present. I do not see that the proposal before the Senate will do anything other than enable this organisation to linger on for another two years or so before it comes back to the Parliament. By then it will probably be so financially destitute that the only option the Government will have will be to wind it up. Instead, it should say to the body at this stage: `You ought to be in the private sector. This is the best way we can put you in the private sector; you take it over. Here is a financial package that will enable you to take it over on reasonable terms; you take it over'. I am sure that that would give it an injection of adrenalin that would be needed to revive this organisation so that once again it is a great body of which all Australians can be proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Amendment Bill. Having listened to the debate, I reiterate that the Government considers it important to continue with the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. The matters raised by the Opposition certainly have not dissuaded the Government from this course of action. I remind the Senate that SMEC has the role of flag carrier for the Australian engineering consultancy industry and this role alone warrants Government financial support. If the SMEC activities were to be curtailed through sale or disbandment, there is no guarantee that void could be filled effectively by another Australian organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: In an article entitled `Top International Design Firms', the Engineering News Record, an American journal, rated the SMEC as the forty-first most successful organisation. The next Australian firm is listed at 154th spot which demonstrates the success the organisation has had in the past and the crucial nature of the role it is fulfilling in terms of the promotion of Australian engineering consultancy services. The loss of overseas projects which would follow from the abolition of SMEC would undoubtedly mean the loss of our skill base which, as honourable senators know, has been built up over a long period. We predict that there would be an immense loss to the Australian economy as a consequence. The Opposition in the very last hour has foreshadowed amendments which are not acceptable to the Government. I will give more explanation for our rejection of those amendments in the debate in the Committee stage. At this point I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the second reading debate we gave notice that we would oppose the legislation. As a result, I have listened to all the speakers and I have read Hansard very carefully. The position is really very clear. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) was very critical in another place-mainly by innuendo-of selected issues that he introduced as requiring improvement. The amendments indicate that he was looking for improvements in the commercial practices, the financial provisions, the redundancy provisions and in the broadening of the board. No Government speaker has covered any of the issues that we have raised. The Opposition expressed concern at the declining business, the declining numbers of staff, the declining profitability and the high contingencies. So far the Government has been unable to give us any of the information for which we have asked and we still have not yet seen the figures for the 1984-85 year or the projections for 1985-86.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has not given one explanation to show us how this Bill would automatically introduce a turnaround in the operation of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation-not one. We are aware of how highly this business rates on its performance among the international design firms of the world and we give credit to it. We do not want SMEC to disappear. I want to see a strong, viable and profitable SMEC, as I said during the second reading debate. Most of all I want to see a home for many years to come for the excellent staff and management that goes with the organisation. However, I am concerned about what will happen now to SMEC, as a government organisation, if it has one more bad year. I believe we must consider first the position of the staff. I do not think that the staff of the organisation are being given adequate consideration at this time. What will the Government do if there is another bad year? The Government plan, through this legislation, will not provide security for the staff and the organisation, and no Government speaker showed us how it could.

I implore the Government not to take the sort of action which can do no more than allow the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation to just fade away. I am a great appreciator of the people involved; I greatly appreciate the work that they have done in so many places. I am not in any doubt that the present staff can continue to make a very adequate contribution in some way if they are given the opportunity, under the guidance of Mr Price and the operators that are now there.

I have looked at clauses 6 and 7 very closely. When one looks at the amendments one is reminded a bit of the old woodheap axe. By the time we change the Corporation, the functions and the powers, will it still be the same Corporation that we have been dealing with? While those changes have been proposed, I cannot see that they will really change the operation of SMEC in any way. I cannot see how the people of SMEC will see any difference as far as their future is concerned. Clauses 6 and 7 are props clauses; they are not reconstruction clauses. I would like to see reconstruction clauses. I believe it is necessary for SMEC itself and especially for the staff that we should make big changes which will alter the whole function. We have pursued amendments and I am sorry that they have not been universally agreed by our friends the Australian Democrats. I think it would be inconsistent if we did not support them in the light of the Australian Dairy Corporation case. It would be inconsistent if we did not pursue them, if the Government did not pursue them and, equally, if the Democrats did not pursue them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you introduce them when you first spoke about it?

—Senator Siddons asks why we did not introduce them earlier. As a matter of fact this matter was not picked up in the House of Representatives by either the Government or the Opposition at the time. It was not picked up in here until some time on Thursday or Friday and it has taken us quite an amount of time to get the wording right and to produce the amendments in a form that could go forward. TALK.START.PARA: —When we adjourned for the evening meal we were in the Committee stage of considering the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Amendment Bill. I seem to be getting a blank look across the table, so I am obliged to go on and draw the Senate's attention to the report on the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries, which was a unanimous report. I am pleased to see in the chamber the Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, who was, with me and others, a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations which reported concern about subsidiaries of statutory authorities. SPEECH.PARA: I am surprised that the Government has not accepted the proposed amendments. I am surprised to hear-outside the chamber, but ultimately it will be disclosed-that the Australian Democrats are not prepared, apparently, to support the proposed amendments. I would have thought that the amendments were--

TALK.START.PARA: —Reasonable.

—Not just reasonable, as one of my colleagues says, but apolitical. I would have thought that they had nothing to do with political parties, but very much to do with the control of the Parliament and the control of Ministers over statutory authorities created by the national Parliament at the request of the Government. After all, all we are proposing in these amendments is, firstly; that the Corporation shall not join in the formation of a partnership or a company unless the Minister has approved in writing of the participation of the Corporation in that partnership or company. How any Minister of the Crown can say that he does not want that control is absolutely beyond me. I see Senator Button looking at the proposed amendment. I hope that he reads and digests it. It is not a difficult one. It would give him control over his own statutory corporations. I would have thought that that is totally apolitical and has nothing to do with being a member of the Liberal Party, the Labor Party or even the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: The second proposed amendment is that after giving approval, the Minister should approve the creation of a subsidiary. He would not have to tell the Parliament at that stage. After the subsidiary has been established, then the Minister shall lay before each House of the Parliament, within 15 sitting days of that House, a statement of the particulars of the partnership or the company that has been created. In other words, we would like to see the memorandum and articles of association, or the partnership constitution, which the subsidiary is establishing. Again I say to parliamentarians-and this time I turn to the Democrats, they will never be in the Ministry, but they will remain in the Parliament, one presumes, although I do not know for how long-that this would give them an opportunity to find out that a statutory corporation has created a subsidiary, and it would give them an opportunity to find out what that subsidiary proposed to do. But apparently the Democrats do not like that proposal.

The next amendment we are proposing is that the Corporation shall not join in the formation of a partnership or a company which has any function or power which is not a function or power of the Corporation. That is a very simple amendment. I am pleased to see that some other members of the Government ranks are coming in to listen to what this is all about, because it is vital for the sake of the Parliament. In other words, a corporation should not extend its own powers by creating a subsidiary. The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation could, under the Bill, as at present framed, create a subsidiary which would have power to enter into trade. It could set up a subsidiary which could create a McDonalds and go into the fast food business. That is the way the legislation is framed at present. There is no control. The Parliament does not have any control over it. We are proposing by this legislation to allow this authority to create subsidiaries and we will not even find out what the subsidiary will be allowed to do, let alone being able to restrict the powers and functions of that subsidiary to make sure it does not extend the power of the statutory corporation.

If the Ministers do not believe that that is a possibility, let me remind them of what happened with Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. We heard Senator Walsh, when he was on this side of the chamber, make repeated speeches attacking Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd and what it had done. He made all sorts of speeches attacking it when he was on this side of the chamber. Now that he is on the Government side of the chamber, apparently the activities of subsidiaries such as that are perfectly all right, because, after all, he is now in government and he does not have to worry about this sort of thing. Well, I am worried about it and I believe that my colleagues on this side of the chamber are very worried about these sudsidiaries. I remind Senator Walsh that he was a subscriber to the unanimous report of the Senate Standing Committee, which said that in future, this sort of limitation should be placed on subsidiaries of statutory authorities.

The final amendment which the Opposition parties are proposing is that when the authority itself reports to Parliament, it will tell the Parliament what its subsidiary has been doing. Again, how any parliamentarian could find anything wrong with that is absolutely beyond me. In the past, statutory authorities have been able to get away with not disclosing to the national Parliament what their subsidiaries have been doing. In fact, I believe that in the past a number of authorities have managed to get away without telling their Ministers what they have been up to, certainly not in detail. I would have thought that the whole thing had nothing to do with what party one belongs to. I would have thought that even the left wing of the Labor Party would support the proposed amendment-although I know it would be most unusual. But it is beyond belief that the Government can come here and say that the proposed amendments are not reasonable and that it is not prepared to accept them. How the Democrats could have the audacity to say that they are members of parliament and that they are representing the interests of the people of Australia but are not prepared to accept these amendments, is absolutely beyond me, because, as I said, to my mind the amendments are totally apolitical. They have to do with the control of the national Parliament over statutory authorities and their subsidiaries. I can see that Senator Tate is anxious to tell me where I am wrong. I shall sit down to allow him to do so, because I shall be very interested to hear what part of what I am saying is not correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills, which were floating around all through the autumn session, are an indication that, once again, the current Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) brought them in with little or no discussion with the various rural organisations. The legislation had passed through the House of Representatives before the National Farmers Federation even had a chance to meet and discuss it. As I have said, once again we have an indication of the apparent contempt in which this Government holds the rural industry by bringing in these various pieces of legislation. Negotiations between the Government and the NFF were held. Various amendments were proposed-some by the NFF-some of which were not accepted by the Government and so the drama went on. In fact, this legislation was never discussed in the Senate before we rose for the winter recess. I am led to believe-I find it rather astounding-that Mr Kerin claimed that the Opposition blocked the passage of these Bills through the Senate. Of course, anybody who had anything to do with the Bills and who was waiting to speak on them would know that that was not the case. They were listed quite regularly on the Notice Paper and on the red business sheet for the day, but because of the discussions that were going on, they never quite made it before the list was ruled off and we went home for the winter recess.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had the consultations and negotiations and we now have amendments that have been agreed to by the Government and the NFF. I understand that Senator Cooney will foreshadow those amendments when he speaks after me. Those amendments will be moved in the Committee stage and the Opposition will support them. They relate mainly to the Rural Industries Research Bill 1985 and a couple of consequential amendments relate to the Rural Industries Research (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1985.

Despite all the problems that the rural industries have had, such as the weather and markets, they still represent 45 per cent of our exports. I think it is essential that the people of Australia realise that, at a time when our current account deficit is in the vicinity of $10 billion, the rural industries still play their part in our balance of trade. Of course, it is necessary for research to be done to help the industry in its marketing, in developing new strains or breeds, or whatever it is that is needed to upgrade the herds and the grain crops to keep us in the forefront of world primary produce and thus help us with our balance of payments. I saw some interesting figures the other day that indicated that the debt accrued by the rural industries currently stands at $6 billion, which works out at about $35,000 per farm. Currently, the average farm income is less than $7,000. That indicates that all is not bright with the primary industries even though they make a substantial contribution to our balance of trade.

The Rural Industries Research Bill amalgamates existing rural research legislation and provides one Act for the administration of rural industry research funds. As I understand it, at present there are 14 trust accounts covering barley, chicken meat, cotton, dried fruits, dairying, fish, honey, oilseeds, pigs, poultry, wheat, wine, wool and tobacco. The Federal Government will help with dollar for dollar assistance for research. Of course, these dollars will be obtained by means of levies on the various commodities I have mentioned.

One major concern which has been expressed all the way through, which has not been addressed by amendment, is the Government's attempt to recover administrative costs from the various bodies. In fact, under this Bill, it would appear that the Minister can direct any research council to pay Department of Primary Industry administrative costs without any accountability to the industry. A statutory charge of about 84 per cent of all salaries seems to be charged on top of those salaries in the area of administration. I will look at a couple of those things in a minute. It is interesting that the Australian Chicken Meat Federation, in a letter to Mr Hunt, pointed out this fact. The letter, from Dr J. G. Fairbrother, stated:

Our industry is not opposing the proposed legislation. We believe we can operate within the legislation without any detrimental effect on the research program. We are concerned however that the Department of Primary Industry is embarking on a cost recovery program which is out of proportion to the service offered. Nevertheless we see little point in assuming the role of secretariat . . . ourselves.

I raise that point because there is concern; the industries that are encompassed in this legislation are worried about the administrative costs. I give the example of dairying. The expenditure on research programs for dairying was $1.4m over 60 projects with administrative costs of $78,478. Yet for beef, which is not within this program, there was an expenditure of $12.2m, or about 10 times that spent on dairying, on 180 projects with administrative costs of only $51,000. We are also concerned that the charges may soak up a disproportionate amount of funds in the smaller industries. While administrative charges take up only 5 per cent of wool funds, administrative charges take up to 20 per cent of poultry research funds and 17 per cent of honey funds. The National Farmers Federation actually took this up in one of its proposed amendments, which was to delete clause 9 (1) (e), but I understand that the Minister did not agree to that and in his letter stated:
I am not prepared to accept your proposed amendment regarding cost recovery for Investment Management.
However, he did give this undertaking in page 2 of his letter:

I undertake that my Department will continue to review the administration of investment services and to consult annually with Research Council Chairpersons on the key elements of costs to be recovered. I will also have this matter discussed at the annual RIRF co-ordination meeting. Through these two means, industry will be provided with an opportunity to assess the efficiency with which investment management is conducted. I will also have these details clearly stated in the Senate debate, which action, as you are aware, brings an obligation for implementation of the action so stated.

With that guarantee from the Minister, the NFF did not seek to pursue its amendment to delete clause 9 (1) (e). As I have said, this legislation is here in the autumn session because of lack of consultation with the industries. They ran into all sorts of problems. The consultation did take place, there has been agreement and the amendments will be made. As I have said, Senator Cooney will foreshadow amendments. We in the Opposition will support those amendments and thus support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some comments to add to those that Senator Collard has already addressed to the Senate. As he has said, the Rural Industries Research Bill 1985, in its eventual form after the amendments to be proposed by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) have been inserted, will be agreed to by the Senate. As I understand it from Senator Macklin, the Australian Democrats will also support it. Senator Collard has said some generous things about the Bill. However, one objection which he had was to the provisions of clause 9 (1) (e) which requires that, from the moneys in the research funds, payments be made for the management of the various funds. He said that, depending on the fund involved, such management costs will take a disproportionate amount of the income in the funds. He said that, depending on the fund involved, such management costs will take a disproportionate amount of the income in the funds.

SPEECH.PARA: It is to be remembered in this context that the Government is putting in half of the amounts in the funds, up to a level equivalent to half a per cent of the gross value of production of the particular industry. It should also be remembered that one of the ideas of this Bill is to make research more separate than perhaps it has hitherto been from government. Those two considerations make it proper, at least at this stage, that the management funds be taken from the research funds rather than that they be paid for by the Government.

Senator Collard pointed out, quite correctly, that the rural industry is still central to the economy of the Australian nation. Of course, I agree with that. This Government, in recognising that, recognises the value of investment in the rural industry, particularly of research in that industry. For that reason it has worked closely with the rural industry in getting this Bill into the form it will be after the amendments have been made. In that respect, it has conferred, as Senator Collard said, with the National Farmers Federation.

The Bill will upgrade the operations of at least 11 rural industry research funds. The philosophy behind all this is that industry and government in this area should in the future act together, as they have in the past. It is intended that from now on the rural industry research councils will be more commercial in their orientation. In that context there has been much discussion recently on privatisation of government bodies. I make the point that, in considering whether something ought to be privatised and in considering whether government ought to enter into the field of any particular industry, the question is not so much whether privatisation as a creed is correct; the consideration is whether a particular result can be more effectively obtained from the private sector, the public sector or, as in this case, a combination of both. It is my submission to the Senate that this case is a very good example of how government and the private sector in the form of rural industry can get together to set out a plan which will help, as Senator Collard has said, a very central industry, a very vital industry to the Australian economy.

It is hoped that the partnership that will be formed through this will be most effective. It will be interesting to see how things have gone at the end of the five-year period contemplated in this Bill as the first of the planned periods that will be addressed by the various councils. I hope that Senator Collard will be back here then so that perhaps at that stage we can debate how things have gone.

There are three features of the Bill which I wish to comment on at this stage. Firstly, this Bill provides for greater participation by each rural industry concerned in the direction of the form of research into its own factors. In other words, the machinery set up by the Bill-this will be particularly so in its amended form-will enable an industry to give direction to the form of research which it considers is correct for its industry. As the amendments which I will come to shortly show, it also contemplates that the Minister for Primary Industry, particularly in the initial stage, will give an indication of where he thinks that research ought to be carried out and an indication of what he considers are the correct priorities in investigating the way in which particular rural industries can be affected. That is the first thing.

Secondly, in a sense the Bill will deregulate research in rural industry more than has been the case to date. Up to now the Minister has given very precise directions as to how research in any particular industry ought to occur. Under this amendment, the Minister will give his initial indications of where he thinks research ought to occur in the five-year period. The council will then be able to direct its own research unhampered by any close direction from the Minister. To that extent, these Bills will open up the area of research and make it freer from government direction than was previously the case.

The third thing the Bill will do is to require the council to play a more active role in the direction in which research ought to go. In other words, up until now the particular body or person undertaking the research has determined to a large extent the direction of that research. As things are arranged under this Bill, it will become the duty of the fund to give direction as to how research funds ought to be devoted. It will work out the appropriate areas of research and look for the appropriate people to carry out research in these areas.

At this stage I indicate the amendments which will be moved by the Minister and which, as I understand it, will find acceptance from the Opposition and by the Australian Democrats. These are the amendments to the Rural Industries Research Bill. The first amendment is to clause 8. The effect of that amendment will be that, in respect of the Barley Research Trust Fund and the Wheat Research Trust Fund, interest earned on the funds will be distributed proportionately amongst the various bodies that contribute to them.

That is the item referred to in proposed new section 9 (1) (e). The Barley Research Trust Fund and the Wheat Research Trust Fund are two funds to which the various States contribute. That amendment will ensure that the interest that becomes available from those funds will be distributed in proportion to the amounts that have been contributed by the various entities.

Under the second amendment, which I have already mentioned, the Minister will determine in writing the form of the research and development that he considers is appropriate for the research fund to develop. That amendment was sought by the industry because, understandably, it was concerned to know exactly what the Minister thought was the appropriate area within which the Research Council should operate and should look for people to carry out the appropriate research. That amendment will make clear to the fund what the Minister considers is the appropriate policy for it to adopt. In the light of that, the fund can go ahead and make its own choices as to where the research ought to go, keeping account of what the Minister has had to say. The Minister shall say what he wants over the five-year period and within that context each fund will make its own choice. It is in that context that I said before that the funds will have much more freedom of choice than was formerly the case.

The next amendment sought, which is agreed to by the Government, relates to the composition of the selection committee. Under that amendment there will be at least three people from the industry, instead of up to three, who will join the selection committee. This will mean that the industry will have the determining voice in deciding who will join particular research councils.

The next amendment is a very sensible one. It is that the selection committee, in determining who shall be on a research council, will advertise the fact that it is looking for people to be appointed to that body. Firstly, it will advertise in newspapers that circulate throughout Australia, and, secondly, by giving notice in writing to orgainsations in the relevant industry which may be concerned to have people appointed to the particular council. Again, that will ensure that the work of the council is known to the best people available. Hopefully, several applications will come forward so that the range of talent available can be looked at and the best person can be obtained from that area.

As I understand it, they are the amendments to the main Bill. There are also some consequential amendments to the subsidiary Bill, which go to matters of drafting only and which cause no particular concern to the Senate. In the light of the amendments which will be moved by the Minister, the Bill is very non-controversial. The fact that the Bill is non-controversial does not mean that it is not one of the more important Bills to come before this place. Hopefully, it will advance rural industry in Australia and will help it over the struggles it is going through presently. The Bill has come before the Senate after discussion with all the appropriate bodies, including the National Farmers Federation, and it has unanimous support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Rural Industries Research Bill and cognate Bills, including Bills covering the tobacco industry and assistance to the poultry industry. The Tobacco Charge Bills provide that the various tobacco levies will go to the Australian Tobacco Board once the tobacco industry has come under the Rural Industries Research Act. The Poultry Industry Levy Amendment Bill and the Poultry Industry Assistance Amendment Bill will apportion part of the hen levy to research, although the hen levy will be abolished from 1 July 1987. The Rural Industries Research Bill embraces rural industries and consolidates them under one Bill. As my colleague Senator Collard, said, the rural industries are diverse. They include barley, cotton, dried fruits, oil-seed, pigs, poultry, dairying, honey, tobacco and wheat. More industries may be added by later legislation from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing industry research committees are to be replaced by research councils of five to nine members for each industry and the research council selection committee will be created. The committee consists of a chairperson appointed by the Minister, a ministerial appointee from the area of science research and development or marketing, a representative from the Agricultural Council and one nominee from the National Farmers Federation. We are told that research councils will be accountable, having their annual report tabled in Parliament, and that the chairperson will present the annual report to an executive meeting of the industry body. One factor that concerns the various research councils is the heavy cost that they fear they will experience as a result of the Department of Primary Industry administering these councils. I do not wish to be derogatory to the Department of Primary Industry but it is a fact of life that this Department will have a lot heavier charges as it has a lot more overheads. Thus its charges will be quite substantial compared with those that would be incurred if the rural industries research councils were responsible for running their own management. This is one of the main points that concern all the various industries. People are concerned that a heavy percentage of the costs will go on administering the research councils.

The Bill is presented by the Government as a commitment by it to increase rural research. However, my scrutiny of the Bill does not indicate that. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised increases to rural research in the last election campaign. This was one of his many promises made during the last election. In fact, this Bill imposes a limit on the Federal Government's contribution to rural research, whereas before there was no such limit on its contribution. The Government matched dollar for dollar any amount put into rural research. Now the Federal Government is limiting its dollar-for-dollar contribution to 0.5 per cent or 5c in the dollar on the annual gross value of production. Over this level the industry contribution will not be matched by the Government. This was not the case under the previous Act. Yet the Government has indicated that this Bill will increase rural research. I say that this is not so, that it will limit rural research. At present-not in five years-there are already rural industries that are paying more than 0.5 per cent of their gross annual value of production. I believe there are two industries in this position; one is the barley industry. The limit introduced by the Bill means that the industry contribution of more than 0.5 per cent will not be matched by the Government, so I fail to see how, by putting a limit on its contributions to research funding, the Government can represent that it is increasing its contribution to rural research.

The limitation imposed by this Bill is a double limitation. First, it places a limit on the Government's contribution where one did not exist before; secondly, it limits the amount of the industry's contribution. When times are bad and production rates are down, the Government's contribution to rural research will go down. This will happen at a time when rural research is most needed. This does not show any appreciation of the needs of the rural industries. I will give an example of that. In the wheat industry there is a continual breakdown of old varieties of wheat as they succumb to new types of disease. This is a natural, botanical process that requires continuing research to fund new varieties which will be resistant to known diseases and known pests.

There is also a continuing need for the development of better quality standards as our export markets change in their demands. Rural research has made a major contribution to keeping Australia's produce competitive on world markets and has led to Australia's proud boast of being one of the most efficient rural producers in the world. As both Senator Cooney and Senator Collard have indicated, 40 per cent of our export earnings come from rural exports. When the Labor Government refuses to hold down our deficit, our export earnings are very important to this country and should be given every encouragement instead of being subject to the limitations that this Bill proposes. It is acknowledged by experts that agriculture will remain the most important single source of export earnings for Australia for at least the rest of this century. In imposing cost after cost on the rural sector, this Government fails to understand that rural industries are the only way that we can meet our commitments to our national debt. With 40 per cent of our export income coming from rural production, it is absolutely essential that we keep on top of rural research.

Since the 1960s the volume of agricultural production has been growing at a rate of 2.8 per cent and it cannot be denied that rural research has made a great contribution to this figure. Yet despite this, and despite relatively good seasonal conditions, farm income is predicted to fall this year by 17 per cent. We have all heard time and again that the average farm income is $7,000 per farmer per year.

The Labor Government has shown its attitude to all research, including rural research, by its treatment of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. In the August Budget I believe the funds to the CSIRO were cut by 3 per cent. The National Party in particular takes a special interest in the CSIRO, not only because of its proud record of rural research, but also because the organisation was established in 1926 as a National Party initiative. With great foresight the National Party saw the CSIRO as being of great importance; therefore it organised its funding to be held in a trust fund so that forward planning could be made with confidence. This also attracted public financial contributions of considerable proportion. Labor governments have been attacking the CSIRO ever since then. The Scullin Labor Government attacked its resources and the Chifley Government altered its independent basis, which removed the public contribution. To this day the Labor Government continues to attack and undermine the CSIRO with a 3 per cent or $24.9m Budget cut.

The CSIRO was giving priority to the area of water research, but Budget cuts affected irrigation research in areas such as salinity problems, high crop yields with economic water use and safe ways of reusing water. Even the Minister for Science, Mr Barry Jones, in answering a question from Mr Hunt, indicated that he wished that more of the CSIRO's funds could be turned away from rural research and put into secondary and tertiary manufacturing research. That would just constitute another broken Labor Government promise on water resources. There is a great deal of fear in the various research councils. They have agreed to go along with the amendments to this Bill as being the best they can expect. They fear that although they have not lost control of the research boards they have lost numbers. They also have grave reservations about the costs that will be imposed. As has already been indicated by my colleague Senator Collard, the Honey Research Committee will have 17 per cent of its research budget taken up by administrative costs within the Department of Primary Industry and the dairy industry will have 20 per cent of its research funds going to pay management commitments to the Department of Primary Industry.

When presenting this Bill the Minister referred to the accountability provisions, which are very acceptable. The National Party believes firmly in the principle of accountability for government spending.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in Queensland. You do not have a Public Accounts Committee.
—Order!

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for your protection. I look forward to the consistency of policy that the Federal Government and Senator Walsh say they are going to provide on public spending. I wish that consistency had been forthcoming in relation to the payments made to the meat inspectors at Mudginberri when they would not perform their duties and cross the picket line. I would like to know where Senator Walsh was when that happened and why he was not giving a lead to help Australia maintain her export industries. He was very quiet then. He always sets himself up as the de facto Queensland Government outside Queensland. It is a great disappointment that the Rural Industries Research Bill represents another broken promise made by the Labor Government as recently as the last election. The Government has chosen to represent it as a measure to boost rural research. Unfortunately, when viewed with the Government's cuts to the CSIRO, and now with the limitations imposed on the Government contribution under this Bill, research for our rural industries will not receive the assistance that it rightly deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major Bill in the package we are discussing, the Rural Industries Research Bill, concerns the restructuring of the rural research boards as they affect the major commodities in Australia. The introduction of this Bill into the House of Representatives in May was, I think, an interesting example of what has gone wrong with much of the rural legislation that has been presented. The Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives without the type of discussion that was needed with the various research councils, when it could have been expected that many of these groups had a valuable contribution to make to its drafting and to the various aspects which concerned their research efforts.

SPEECH.PARA: After the passage of the Bill in the House of Representatives the Government entered into discussion with the National Farmers Federation and, as a result, there has been acceptance by the Government of eight major amendments and a number of consequential amendments. The intent was originally that the Rural Industries Research Bill and allied Bills would have passed both Houses during the last session, but that was not possible due to time factors. Hence this is the first occasion on which the Senate has had a chance to debate the Bills. The Government has foreshadowed that it will be moving amendments in the Committee stage to a number of principal items that the National Farmers Federation, on behalf of some, but not all, of the research councils, has put forward and the Government has agreed to accept. I will leave more detailed comments on a number of those amendments until the Committee stage.

The rural research effort in Australia has always been extensive and, over the years, has been funded in a variety of ways. The Government has used this Bill to bring in some type of systematisation to the various methods which have been used for the various commodities. The research efforts on various commodities have tended to be of historical development and, in the past, certainly, in some industries, have been patchy. However, recently there has been a telling point with these industries and their research efforts that I am concerned we might lose in the implementation of this Bill.

I believe the amendments will alleviate most of the problems I have, but I would still like to refer to the essential notion that I think is too often missed in research. I refer to the notion of dissemination. The Australian community, in a wide range of fields, has been eminently successful in research in world terms. As a nation in our research effort we have contributed far and above certainly all the nations in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development listing per head of population. Our major failing, and it is one that the Minister for Science, Barry Jones, points to time and again, is in the implementation of research and not in the research itself.

In the rural sector the construction of the boards, which have had their practitioners on them, has played a very important part in that dissemination. I shall spell out in general how many of the people have seen their jobs, and they have carried them out in this fashion. The practitioners have been selected by the commodity councils of one kind or another to serve on those research boards and they have seen their role very largely as representatives of the practitioners. They have brought to the research effort a telling point: What is the practicality of the research which is being carried out? The two types of research of which most people are aware are the fundamental research efforts which are carried on, by and large, in our tertiary institutions and in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, and the applied research that is often funded through these boards. It is the second variety in which I think the practitioners have a particularly important role.

Having urged that research be carried out and having received the results of that research, those people representing the various commodity groups have then gone out and sold that research to the practitioners. They have been eminently successful in that type of operation. There are some suggestions in the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in the House of Representatives that cast doubt, as it were, on that particular activity. In considering these various boards, as I did when we looked at the Bill when it was introduced into the House of Representatives, I was astounded at the effort many of these people put in when travelling around the country, selling to people in various industries the products of the research that had been carried out. No matter how good the research is, if it is not applied it is not worth a dollar. Essentially, in its application and implementation, dissemination is a vital factor that has so often been missing in Australia's research efforts. I am concerned that in some of the moves made in this Bill, that dissemination process will be lessened by putting less reliance on those practitioners who are representatives of the various commodity producers in Australia. It is not an esoteric point by any means. The money which is being expended is coming from the various groups by way of levies, and they wish to see that money used effectively and efficiently. The balance that needs to be maintained in the promotion of basic and applied research, I think, has been and can be maintained almost 100 per cent. I am happy to admit that there are some exceptions-certainly I know of some-but the type of balance which is necessary in rural research has been maintained in the major commodity areas that I have surveyed.

When the Government introduced this Bill, I wrote to a wide range of people who would be affected. It was disappointing to see from the replies of industry councils, those groups representing producers, the lack of consultation that they had had. They were naturally apprehensive about the introduction of legislation with which they had not been involved. It was a very useful activity that occurred, after the passage of the Bill through the House of Representatives, in the entry into swift and meaningful negotiations with those groups. However, I do not believe that that, as a model, is a way to go. Picking that up as an analogy to the type of research that is often referred to, it seems to me that without asking the practitioners in the field and without constantly remaining in touch with them to find out what their pressing concerns are, our research effort will not be applied by those practitioners, who are, after all, in many cases strapped for cash, time and effort in a very tight international commodity field.

That is my only major concern about the Rural Industries Research Bill. We congratulate the Government on its belated discussions with the industry and on the very real way in which it has sought to pick up the additional concerns which have been brought forward on behalf of the various commodity groups by the National Farmers Federation. I should like to say something more about each of those items on technical grounds in Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have concern about the impact of the costs involved in this legislation on the farming community. In relation to the value of production, costs might appear to be minimal; but in relation to the net return, I think they are fairly significant. The great worry in the primary industries today is those costs which are beyond the farm gate, in addition to the rapid escalation of on-farm costs. Our rural production is extremely important to the continued growth and development of this country. We recognise that our farmers are amongst the most efficient in the world. It has been estimated that the average Australian farmer produces enough for 70 people. In this decade, agriculture earned around 43 per cent of Australia's export earnings-an unrivalled contribution to our economy. The 1984-85 record return of $14.5 billion will be passed on this financial year and the cash flow from that could be significantly greater because of the devaluation of the dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: Agriculture, both directly and indirectly, provides employment for more than three million Australians and, in addition to exports, it produces the raw materials for a considerable part of Australia's manufacturing industry. The quality of our agricultural production is of world-class standard and we can boast of a renowned skill in agricultural research and techniques, developed by individuals and other bodies, including the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Why then, if we are doing so well, do we need new legislation such as the Rural Industries Research Bill? It is because appearances are deceiving. Our rural economy is really in a very poor position. Our farmers are fighting a seemingly endless and unwinnable battle against the pressure of rising costs, on the one hand, and despair in the face of stagnant commodity prices in often over-supplied markets on the other. Despite the record value of our rural production, farm incomes are again expected to fall by about 17 per cent this financial year and by a further 20 per cent next year, despite the effects of devaluation. I think that those who attended the rally of farmers in Canberra were very impressed by the sincerity of their utterances and their concerns. Judging from the number of placards, one of their major concerns was the big increase in fuel costs.

Our ability to compete on world markets, unfortunately, is declining. Over the last 10 years, our share of world exports has fallen from 1.7 per cent to 1.3 per cent and, therefore, we should be concerned that our penetration of most overseas markets, especially in South-East Asia, has declined. In my view, our declining competitiveness is not a reflection on our primary producers today. We have been the victims so often of unfair and, at times, unscrupulous competition from such centres as the European Economic Community. Its massive over-production has had disastrous effects on world markets, and has kept commodity prices low. Subsidies to farmers cost the EEC taxpayers $70 billion in 1984, and their mountains of surplus beef, butter, wine, fruit, cereals, sugar, vegetable oil and potatoes have been literally dumped on many of our traditional markets, at prices with which we cannot compete. Aggressive marketing programs by the United States, which include subsidies, export benefits and bonuses for new sales, will deal further blows in both income terms and lost marketing opportunities for our primary producers. It would not matter how efficient our farmers were, they would not be able to compete without similar subsidies.

However, we cannot blame the EEC for all our problems. New Zealand, with better marketing strategies and often-as in the case of sheepmeat-with a better product, has captured some of our markets. New Zealand recognised changing consumer demand years ago, and, through research, developed products that would meet these changing needs. The fact that the New Zealanders have plant variety rights legislation must give them a distinct advantage in the horticultural field. They are already producing new varieties of fruit and vegetables which are very acceptable to South-East Asian and Pacific markets. If we are to reverse our present uncompetitiveness, we must put more money and expertise into research and the development of new products and new markets. I wholeheartedly support the move to co-ordinate rural research and development, and to develop a more sound administrative structure to do this. I agree that it is of the greatest importance that those who administer and undertake research are accountable to both the Government and the industries and that the greatest possible returns are made from each dollar spent on research.

The 11 industries coming under the umbrella of this legislation will be encouraged to take a much greater part in the development of their products and the direction of rural research. Australia's economic advancement in the future will largely depend on our rural industries' ability to remain competitive and profitable, and attuned to changing market demands. Thus, the development of a progressive and constructive five-year plan for rural research, in addition to an annual research and development program, I believe, is a step in the right direction. However, the best scientists, with the best marketing team and the greatest agricultural production experts in the world, will be a waste of time and taxpayers' money if there are not enough farmers left to produce the goods in the long run. Unfortunately, many farmers are being forced to sell their farms because farming can no longer offer a family a reasonable standard of living, a reasonable return on investment or even a reliable income.

World-wide investigation by the National Farmers Federation has shown that Australian farmers pay up to three times the price paid for basic farm inputs by American and New Zealand farmers. The Australian farm cost problem is mainly a function of five government activities; namely, excessive tariffs on many imported goods, excessive borrowing and spending at all levels by governments, a rigid labour market, over-regulated service industries, particularly transport, and government charges and taxes on imports. Research and development are vital. Until this problem and other problems are resolved, I am afraid that our rural returns will continue to decline in real terms.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of this Bill is to authorise payments in 1985-86 arising out of decisions, taken at the 30 May 1985 Loan Council meeting, which fall outside the provisions of the Financial Agreement Act 1928. Specifically, this Bill seeks to authorise: The payment of general purpose capital grants to the States in 1985-86; the prepayment of capital grants during the first six months of 1986-87, pending passage of similar legislation in that year; the continued payment in 1985-86, 1986-87 and 1987-88 of loans on concessional terms and conditions of amounts nominated by the States and the Northern Territory from their approved borrowing programs as being for the purposes of public housing; and to provide scope for the payment of concessional housing loans in the first six months of 1986-87, 1987-88 and 1988-89.
The amount to be advanced to each State under this last provision is limited to an amount equal to one half of the amount it was permitted to nominate in the previous year.

Loan Council decided to hold the total State governments' borrowing programs to $1,564.5m in 1985-86, the same money level as in 1984-85. This will assist the Commonwealth in further reducing the public sector borrowing requirement in 1985-86.

Since 1975-76 one-third of the State governments' borrowing programs have been provided by the Commonwealth as interest free capital grants. For 1985-86 only, the capital grant provision is to be increased by 7 per cent ($36.5m), to $558.0m (or approximately 35.7 per cent of the total program) and the loan component reduced by an equivalent amount.

The effect of these grants is to relieve the States of debt charges (that is, interest payments and sinking fund contributions) which they would otherwise have to pay, and the grants accordingly have a substantial beneficial effect on the overall financial positions of the States.

The grants were introduced to help States finance works, such as schools and other capital works, from which debt charges are not normally recovered. There are, however, no conditions attaching to the manner in which the grants are applied by the States.

The arrangements whereby the States and the Northern Territory are able to nominate part of their approved borrowing programs for public housing were introduced in 1982-83. As a condition of the payment of these funds, the Bill contains provision that a State of the Northern Territory must be able to meet its matching requirements for the purposes of the Housing Assistance Act 1984. Subject to that, the nominated funds will be provided to the States and the Northern Territory at the loan terms and conditions set out in the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, and hence will bear interest at the highly favourable rate of 4 1/2 per cent per annum and will be repayable over 53 years.

In deciding to continue the arrangements the Government has recognised the considerable contribution made by the arrangements to the financing of public housing in the States and the encouragement it has given the States to increase their housing expenditures. However, the concession represents a large and growing ongoing cost to the Commonwealth in terms of the reduced interest payments received from the States, and as a result, the Government has found it necessary to introduce some limits on the application of the concession.

The Bill therefore imposes limits on the proportion of Loan Council borrowings which States and the Territory can nominate of 30 per cent of the loan component of their programs. This exceeds the proportion of the loan component which has so far been nominated by any of the States except for South Australia and Western Australia, which in 1984-85 each nominated the whole of their loans. As a transitional arrangement, the Bill provides that those two States will again be able to nominate the whole of their loans in 1985-86, 60 per cent in 1986-87 and 30 per cent thereafter.
This Bill forms an important part of the Commonwealth's overall financial assistance to the States and the Northern Territory and I therefore commend the Bill to the Senate.
